list.item: Second Grade Magistrate Court sitting at Mwanza

body.p: The convict was not brought before court by the Prisons authorities so I proceeded to handle the matter in Chambers since no adverse effects would affect the convict. The convict was charged with house breaking and theft contrary to sections 309 (a) and 278 respectively. He was sentenced to 18 months imprisonment with hard labour for house breaking and 18 months for house breaking is grossly inadequate but I will not consider it now as the review judge did not raise the issue and much more that the convict is not present to be heard on the matter, so too the State.
The review judge was concerned with the manner plea was taken in an omnibus way and that elements of the offences were not put forward to the accused. I do concur that an
omnibus plea to two counts is irregular. The accused pleaded as such:-
This is irregular as the admission should be to each count separately.

Further, after a guilty plea, the elements of the offences were not put forward to the accused for specific separate admissions. It was stated in Magwaya v The Rep MLR vol 8 at 323 that admission of charge in general words without reference to separate ingredients of the offence is equivocal and defective. However, where a guilty plea is defective it may be cured if accused agreed to statement of facts which is sufficient to substantiate the charge. The accused then confirmed that the facts were correct which facts supported the offences charged.
For the above reason I uphold the conviction but the case may be set down again to consider sentence.
Made in Chambers this 27th day of May 2005 at Blantyre.
